bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Felipe Carbonell Ponce, January 30, 1942

div1.p: Hench inquires about the Cuban government's interest in preserving the site of Camp Lazear. Hench stresses that he does not want the monument dedicated to one person, but rather envisions a Cuban-American memorial.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Felipe Carbonell Ponce, January 30, 1942
div1.opener:
Rochester, Minnesota
January 30, 1942
Had no reply
Dr. Felipe Carbonell Ponce
San Lazaro 413
Habana, Cuba
My dear Doctor PonceCarbonell:
div1.p:
My delay in answering your kind letter of January 12 has been occa-
sioned by my absence from Rochester, attending meetings in the East. Needless to
say, your letter was of great interest to me and it is very gratifying to know that
I have been able to stimulate your interest so effectively. I am of course extremely
anxious to know what results you have had with your continued conversations with
Mr. Salas, Dr. Marruz and above all, with President Batista. You wrote me that Dr.
Marruz was bringing the question before the Council of Ministers a couple of weeks
ago. Have you had any word as to the result of this discussion? Before you wrote
me, I had been in correspondence with the ownder of the property at the site of
Camp Lazear. As you know I obtained from him a deed to the little building and I am
buying some of the land. If governmental action is as slow in your country as it is
in ours on occasion, I cannot be optimistic enough to hope that your government will
at once become interested in this project. Therefore, it seems best to me to continue
my negotiations with the purchase and proper preservation of the former camp site.
I can assure you that if the Cuban government does wish to interest themselves in
this project I will be glad to hand over to the Cuban authorities whatever interests
and rights I have acquired.

You have interpreted my intention with absolute correctness. It is
my intention that the little memorial building should be a monument to the Cuban-
American medical profession and to the brave volunteers both of Finlay's and of the
American commission's who helped to conquer yellow fever. It is not my purpose to
have the monument dedicated to one person. Dr. Ramos was inclined to favor naming it
“The Lazear Memorial”. That would of course be satisfactory to me providing it be
known generally as a Cuban-American medical museum, dedicated to Finlay and his
associates as well as to the Americans. In the brilliant conquest of yellow fever
there is enough glory for all concerned and it is my purpose to heal the wounds that
have been made as a result of the attempts of one or the other person to give more
glory to one or another man. I am interested in your statement that you are decidedly
against transferring the little building from Camp Lazear to the false site. Per-
sonally, I would prefer not to transfer it although I have recognized the merits of
this idea as proposed by Dr. Ramos and others since the little building would be then
so much more close to the Ciudad Militar and the Military Hospital. I think that a
smaller memorial, perhaps a boulder with a bronze plaque or some sort of a monument
might well be erected at the false site, for this is where all the American cases of
experimental yellow fever were cared for and this is actually where Dr. Lazear died.

When the venture gets well under way, certainly an advisory committee
must be formed consisting of certain American and Cuban physicians and governmental
personages most interested in this project. I discussed this with Dr. Charles E.
Finlay last Spring when he was in Havana. I have already raised a little money in
this country for our project but not as yet enough for the purchase of the property
and building of the memorial building to enclose Building No. 1. Indeed, I have been
delayed in getting the venture under full swing because I have not yet been able to
find out exactly how much it would cost to purchase the entire site of Camp Lazear.

I am delighted that you get in touch with Mr. Pogolotti and Mr.
Moran. They are charming gentlemen and have been of the greatest possible help to
Dr. Felipe Carbonell Ponce
- 2 -
January 30, 1942
me. Without them, the true site of Camp Lazear would never have been found and
they must be recognized as perhaps the two most interested persons in Cuba in
this venture. Certainly they should be on any advisory committee that is formed.
I am distressed at not having heard from Mr. Moran for some months and have been
wondering whether he is ill. I certainly hope not.

You may be interested to read a detailed report which I made to
Dr. Dominguez Ramos, which report was prepared on the basis of an investigation
of Mr. Moran, Mr. Pogolotti and myself. A copy of this report is in the library
of the Finlay Institute and is illustrated with maps, various photostats, photo-
graphs, etc., clearly showing our proof for the identification of the true and
false sites of Camp Lazear.
I shall await with great interest further word from you.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
